column4: Is there a way to mount a remote filesystem via SCP (NOT SFPT) in Ubuntu?
sshfs uses sftp asfaik, but i need scp...
i dont think scp and sftp is the same protocol
okay, maybe not, but are you sure the SCP host you try to connect to doesn't work woth sshfs?

yes i am, because its dropbear server on a router which i cant get working with sshfs because dropbear doesnt support sftp... Using winscp with scp protocol works fine, but i need a linux mount option for dropbear (using scp).
have you looked into rcp with encryption, as scp is based on rcp ?
i am just guessing trying to give you pointers. Google is your friend for the details.
look into FUSE also, if you have some programming experience in C, it is almost trivially easy to create your own filesystem
thx, i am googling already, but it told me rcp is the predecessor to scp which works for copying single files to the server, but im searching a mount option for the remote filesystem...
you really need a mount, no possibility for scripts?
or other mount options? rcp, nfs, cifs, etc?

yes i need to mount option, and i prefer not to run an extra server for it because i have very limited memory on my remote host. As winscp works fine with my configuration and scp comes from *nix bg i thought it cant be too difficult to mount it...
what do you offer to create a scpfs ?
i am not sure what you mean by offer, my remote box runs uclibc openwrt and my local desktop box ubuntu x64
i meant you pay me money to create it :P.
u mean there is no other option than writing fuse module for mounting it? i heard of shfs, but it seems abandoned...
i don't know. I'd reckon there is a scpfs module out there somewhere. Or maybe sshfs has scp options.
